III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12202
Section Policy and procedures
Description • (1) An agency shall have and follow written policies
and procedures for all the areas of foster care services
as provided in R400.12203 to R 400.12214.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation A foster care worker is routinely late for parenting time visits.
Investigation Foster Parent 1 was interviewed on 5/28/2025 via telephone.
Foster Parent 1 reported Foster Care Worker (FCW) of Youth A
has been extremely unprofessional since she became the case
worker for Youth A’s case. Foster Parent 1 explained FCW is
unprofessional by being routinely late by 30 minutes or over an
hour or arriving to her home early without notice. Foster Parent 1
reported FCW arrived in her personal vehicle to transport Youth A,
who is 6 months old, to Youth A’s next placement. Foster Parent
1 reported FCW was rushing and did not give her the opportunity
to properly say goodbye to Youth A and FCW did not take all of
Youth A’s belongings from her house to Youth A’s next placement.
Foster Parent 1 reported FCW did not have a car seat for Youth A
to transport but since she was in the process of moving to another
state, she had a car seat and gave it to FCW for Youth A. Foster
Parent 1 reported she did not file a grievance with the agency.
She reported she remembered the dates of 4/29/2025 and
5/23/2025.
Chief Administrator (CA) was interviewed on 5/28/2025 via
telephone. CA reported Foster Parent 1 has never called the
agency and complained about FCW being late for any visits. She
reported FCW was hired on 11/28/2024 and has completed all of
the agency training including transporting foster youths and their
safety. CA reported FCW can transport foster children in their
personal vehicles. She reported she was unaware that FCW
transported her biological children/child to a foster parent home.
She reported if this was an issue for FCW, FCW could have called
the agency and requested back up to transport opposed to taking
her child to a foster parent’s home. CA reported the agency would
2

have identified someone else from the team who could have
transported Youth A while FCW was out of the office. CA reported
coworkers and/or supervisors, and other supportive staff can
always be utilized when a staff member is out of the office
unexpectedly. The CA reported the agency does not have a
written policy on transporting but rather the staff are trained on
agency procedure on transporting youths in their personal
vehicles and safety.
Foster Care Supervisor was interviewed on 5/28/2025 via
telephone. She reported she never received any complaints from
anyone regarding FCW being late to visits or unprofessionalism.
She was unaware that FCW transported her child to a foster
parent home. She had no additional information.
Foster Care Worker (FCW) was interviewed on 6/3/2025 via
telephone. She reported that if she is ever late for an
appointment/visit she calls and informs the foster parent that she
is running late. She reported she has never been an hour late for
a foster home visit nor does she arrive to foster parents’ home
early. She reported she has been trained on transporting foster
youths by an agency focusing on safety. She reported the agency
provided the staff permission to transport foster youths in their
personal vehicles if agency vehicles are not available. She
reported that sometimes all of the agency’s vehicles are in use
therefore staff can use their personal vehicles for transport. FCW
reported Foster Parent 1 was always polite with her and she never
complained to her about being unprofessional or late to any of her
home visits or parenting time visits. FCW stated she was not late
for the 4/29/2025 visit, however this visit included a sensitive
discussion of Foster Parent 1 moving to another state.
FCW reported Foster Parent 1 submitted her 30-day removal for
Youth A. She reported Youth A needed to be removed by
5/24/2025, however this date was a Saturday. She reported she
was unable to transport Youth A to her new placement sooner as
she had been busy with several youths on her case load
throughout the week and did not have time to transport Youth A to
her next placement during the week. She reported she called out
of work on May 23, 2025, because her young daughter was sick
and she did not have a babysitter. She reported she knew she
had to transport Youth A to her next placement, therefore, she put
her daughter (8 years of age) in her personal vehicle and took her
to Foster Parent 1’s home to take Youth A to her next placement.
She reported she was aware that Youth A had a car seat at Foster
Parent 1’s home because she has transported Youth A before and
3

used Youth A’s car seat and this was part of Youth A’s
belongings. FCW said the first thing she looked for when she
arrived to the home of Foster Parent 1 was Youth A's car seat
which was visible as Foster Parent 1 had placed all of Youth A’s
belongings outside of the apartment complex where Foster Parent
1 was residing. She explained Foster Parent 1 was loading her
belongings on a moving truck as she was leaving Michigan and
going to Wisconsin and had set all of Youth A’s belongings
outside on the ground.
FCW reported she got out of her vehicle and inquired about Youth
A. FCW reported Foster Parent 1 reported that Youth A was
inside with one of her relatives. She reported Foster Parent 1
reported the belongings were packed and ready for FCW. FCW
reported she picked up the car seat and put it safely in her vehicle.
She reported she asked Foster Parent 1 if she was going to assist
her in putting Youth A’s other belongings in her vehicle and Foster
Parent 1 said no. FCW reported after loading Youth A’s
belongings in her vehicle, she asked Foster Parent 1 if she could
now transport Youth A to her next placement. FCW reported an
unknown adult brought Youth A outside where Youth A was then
encircled by five adults. She reported Foster Parent 1 told her
these were all relatives of Youth A and the relatives came to her
house to help her pack up and move. FCW reported all of the
relatives began passing Youth A around to each other and kissing
her saying goodbye. FCW reported after about 20 minutes of
saying goodbye, she requested to take Youth A to her next
placement. Foster Parent 1 said her last goodbye, kissed Youth A
and FCW put Youth A in her car seat and transported Youth A to
her next placement which was about 23 minutes away in the same
neighborhood.
FCW explained she did not call the agency to inform them she
was transporting Youth A to her new placement because Youth A
was on her caseload and Youth A was her responsibility. She
denied ever being disrespectful or unprofessional towards Foster
Parent 1.
Foster Parent 2 was interviewed on 6/10/2025 via telephone.
She reported FCW has never been late for any appointments to
her home and that she was always professional.
Foster Parent 3 was interviewed on 6/10/2025 via telephone.
She reported FCW was usually at her house timely and never
came late. She reported FCW is a very good worker, professional
and it shows she cares about children and their safety.
4

Document Reviewed:
• Agency Procedure on transporting youth in their personal
vehicle - The program has 4 agency vehicles that are
available to the team. In the event that an agency vehicle is
not available, staff may use their own vehicle for
transporting clients. There is no agency policy pertaining to
timely attendance for visits.
• Statement of the agency safety regarding car seats - The
agency has approximately 8 car seats available at the
agency for staff to utilize when transporting babies/children
of different ages/sizes. Additionally, all case managers are
trained on car seat safety.
Analysis Based on interviews and documentation reviewed, FCW was
timely with her visits and remained professional. The agency does
not have specific policies or procedures regarding timeliness of
visits.
Consultation:
Consultation was provided regarding if a worker is on leave but
engages in transportation of a youth or a home visit, to report
whereabouts to their direct supervisor.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12211
Section Privacy safeguard
Description • (1) An agency shall safeguard the privacy of a child
and his or her family.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation A foster care worker transported a foster child in her personal
vehicle along with her biological child.
Investigation Foster Parent 1 was interviewed on 5/28/2025 via telephone.
She reported FCW has come to her home at least three or four
times for home visits and brought her biological child with her.
She reported the dates she remembered of this occurring were
4/29/2025 and 5/23/25. Foster Parent 1 reported FCW allowed
her child to remain in the vehicle for at least 30 minutes on
4/30/2025, while the foster home visit occurred. Foster Parent 1
reported she was uncomfortable with FCW’s child being left in the
5

vehicle while FCW was completing her foster home visit. Foster
Parent 1 reported FCW brought her child to her home at least 3
other times leaving the child each time in the car. According to
Foster Parent 1, FCW told her she was going to have to bring her
child with her because she did not have anyone to watch her
daughter.
CA was interviewed on 6/10/2025 via telephone. She reported
she was unaware that FCW was transporting her own child to
home visits. She reported this information was never shared to
her by the FCW and no foster parent has called the agency to
report this information on any of the foster care workers. CA
reported the agency does have policy on confidentiality. She
reported that staff transporting their own children on foster care
home visits with foster children is not allowed. CA reported all
policies are reviewed with staff on an annual basis. She reported
all staff reviewed the policies on professional boundaries and
interaction with clients and their families on 3/14/25 and signed
acknowledgements.
Foster Care Supervisor was interviewed on 5/28/2025 via
telephone. She reported she never received any complaints from
anyone regarding FCW being late to visits or unprofessionalism.
She was unaware that FCW transported her child to a foster
parent home. Foster Care Supervisor is aware of safety issues
and does not support FCW transporting her biological child to the
home of foster parents. Foster Care Supervisor did not discuss
this being against agency policy. She had no additional
information to provide.
FCW was interviewed on 6/3/2025, via telephone. She
reported she did transport her 8-year-old daughter in her personal
vehicle on 5/23/2025, to transport Youth A to her placement. She
reported she had called off to stay home with her daughter
because her daughter was not feeling well. She reported she
could not find a babysitter, so she took her daughter with her
because she was only going to pick up Youth A and transport her
to her next placement which was going to take under an hour.
She reported that her 8-year-old daughter remained in the car
playing with her phone while she picked up Youth A’s belongings
and placed them in the trunk of her car and put Youth A in her car
seat and transported Youth A to her next placement. FCW
reported this was the first time she has taken her child to a foster
home and denied ever leaving her daughter in the car while
completing a foster home visit. She reported that her child is too
6

young to report any confidential information regarding the
placement of the foster youth that was transported on 5/23/2025.
Foster Parent 2 and 3 were interviewed on 6/10/2025 via
telephone. Both Foster Parent 2 and 3 reported FCW has never
brought her child to a foster home visit in their home.
Documents reviewed
• Youth A’s case record was reviewed. Youth A was placed
with licensed/unlicensed relative on 12/12/2024 –
5/23/2025. Placed in a licensed foster home on 5/23/2025
until present.
• Social work contacts reviewed for 4/29/2025, were
verification of Youth A’s well-being. Discussion centered
around 30-day removal due to Foster Parent moving out of
state for better job opportunity, Youth A’s medicals and any
safety issues. None was noted.
• Social work contacts reviewed for 5/23/2025, were
centered around Youth A move to her new foster home. No
issues of safety were noted.
• FCW personnel file was reviewed. She was hired on
11/18/2024. FCW attended CWTI training and completed
training for Methodist orientation checklist that included
transporting of youths, confidentiality, and safeguarding the
rights of children and families. She has no disciplinary
issues in her personnel file.
• Agency Confidentiality policy was reviewed. The policy
discusses safeguarding the privacy of a child and his or her
family and the agency. One statement in the policy states
employee acknowledges and shall abide by all rules and
regulations and laws respecting the use and disclosure of
confidential information including but not limited to HIPAA
and FERPA. The Confidentiality policy is large in nature
and covers children in care, families at Methodist Children
Home.
Analysis The agency has a policy on confidentiality, safeguarding the
privacy of a child and his or her family. FCW admitted she took
her child with her to transport Youth A to her next placement on
5/23/2025. She admitted she did not report this information to her
administration. CA was unaware FCW had her biological child with
her when transporting Youth A to her licensed foster home
placement on 5/23/2025. CA reported FCW had other options and
staff transporting their own children on home visits to foster homes
is not allowed, but this is not a part of any specific agency policy.
7

Technical Assistance:
Technical assistance was provided to ensure staff expectations
are documented in policies and/or procedures and communicated
to staff.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
